H0.text: which condition would most likely require nutrition delivered through tpn. Short Bowel Syndrome

H1.text: which condition would most likely require nutrition delivered through tpn. Necrotizing Enterocolitis

H2.text: which condition would most likely require nutrition delivered through tpn. Intestinal Atresia

H3.text: which condition would most likely require nutrition delivered through tpn. gastroschisis

A4.text: Diseases that would require the use of TPN include: Short bowel syndrome

A5.text: TPN may be the only feasible option for providing nutrition to patients who do not have a functioning gastrointestinal tract or who have disorders requiring complete bowel rest, including bowel obstruction, short bowel syndrome, gastroschisis, gastroparesis, prolonged diarrhea regardless of its cause, very severe Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis, and certain pediatric GI disorders including congenital GI anomalies and necrotizing enterocolitis.

A6.text: In newborn infants with less than 10% of expected intestinal length, 5 year survival is approximately 20%.

A7.text: Occasionally, nutrients need to be given through an intravenous line, known as parenteral nutrition.
